column2: It seems that the derivation of Chicago's nickname as the ""Windy City"" isn't as obvious as I would have thought. There are two viable theories. First the weather can be breezy, with wind blowing in off Lake Michigan. The effect of the wind is exaggerated by the grid-layout adopted by city planners after the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. The second theory is that the ""windy"" means being full of bluster. Sportswriters from the rival city of Cincinnati were fond of calling Chicago supporters ""windy"" in the 1860s and 1870s, meaning that they were full of hot air in their claims that the Chicago White Stockings were superior to the Cincinnati Red Stockings."
